title: Scaling and Expanding the Use of Registered Apprenticeships in Industries and the Federal Government and Promoting Labor-Management Forums

enrichment.summary: This executive order directs federal agencies to increase the use of Registered Apprenticeship programs to provide paid training and career development opportunities, especially for underserved workers, while also encouraging cooperative labor-management forums to improve workplace relations and productivity. It establishes an interagency working group to coordinate these efforts, integrate apprenticeship opportunities into federal hiring, grants, and contracts, and promote equity and workforce development across the federal government.
potential_concerns: The shift toward Registered Apprenticeships may inadvertently create barriers for individuals in underserved communities (e.g., african-americans-black-americans, hispanic-latino-americans, women) if recruitment and outreach efforts are not sufficiently inclusive or culturally competent, undermining workforce equity goals.

Federal employees participating in Registered Apprenticeship programs may experience challenges balancing apprenticeship requirements with their existing job duties, potentially causing workload strain or impacting retention.

Union members might perceive the expansion of Registered Apprenticeships as a threat to traditional hiring and seniority systems, creating tension in labor-management relations despite the goal of cooperative forums.

Agencies’ incorporation of Registered Apprenticeships into procurement and grants may increase administrative burdens on contractors and grantees who must comply with new workforce requirements, potentially impacting project costs and timelines.

The policy’s focus on apprenticeship pathways within federal hiring might unintentionally limit opportunities for non-apprenticeship qualified applicants, affecting working-age adults and veterans seeking federal employment through other traditional channels.
